Description: All non-text content has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose
Do: Provide descriptive alt text that conveys the image meaning and context
Don't: Use generic alt text like 'image' or 'photo' or leave alt attribute missing entirely

Description: Decorative images that convey no information must be hidden from assistive technology
Do: Use empty alt attribute or aria-hidden='true' for purely decorative images
Don't: Add descriptive alt text to decorative dividers or background flourishes

Description: Complex images like charts or diagrams need both short alt and long description
Do: Provide short alt plus detailed description via aria-describedby or figcaption
Don't: Rely solely on a short alt attribute for a complex data visualization

Description: SVG elements used as images must have accessible names via title element or aria-label
Do: Add role='img' and a <title> element or aria-label to informative SVGs
Don't: Embed SVG inline without any accessible name or role assignment
Code Example Good: <svg role="img" aria-labelledby="svg-title"><title id="svg-title">Shopping cart with 3 items</title>...</svg>

Description: Normal text (under 18pt or 14pt bold) must have at least 4.5:1 contrast ratio against its background
Do: Use tools to verify contrast ratios during design and ensure all text states meet 4.5:1
Don't: Use light gray text on white backgrounds or rely on color alone to convey information

Description: Large text (18pt+ or 14pt+ bold) must have at least 3:1 contrast ratio against background
Do: Verify heading and large text contrast separately from body text
Don't: Assume large headings automatically pass contrast because they are bigger

Description: User interface components and graphical objects must have at least 3:1 contrast ratio
Do: Ensure form borders icons and focus indicators all meet 3:1 against adjacent colors
Don't: Use very light borders on white inputs or low-contrast icons for critical UI elements

Description: Focus indicators must be visible with sufficient contrast against surrounding content
Do: Use a distinct high-contrast focus ring that is clearly visible on all backgrounds
Don't: Remove default focus outlines without providing a visible custom alternative

Description: Heading levels must be sequential and convey document structure accurately
Do: Use headings in proper order (h1 then h2 then h3) to create a logical outline
Don't: Skip heading levels (h1 to h4) or use headings solely for visual styling

Description: Use proper semantic elements for lists and tabular data so structure is programmatically determinable
Do: Use <ul>/<ol> for lists and <table> with <th> scope for tabular data
Don't:
Use
and
to simulate lists or use tables purely for layout

Description: Use HTML5 landmark elements to define page regions for screen reader navigation
Do: Use <header> <nav> <main> <aside> <footer> as structural landmarks
Don't: Wrap everything in generic <div> elements with no semantic meaning

Description: If audio plays automatically for more than 3 seconds provide a mechanism to pause stop or control volume
Do: Provide visible pause/stop controls and never autoplay audio without user consent
Don't: Autoplay background music or audio with no way to stop or reduce volume

Description: Text can be resized up to 200% without loss of content or functionality
Do: Use relative units (rem/em) and test at 200% browser zoom
Don't: Use fixed pixel sizes that break layout or clip text when zoomed

Description: All functionality must be operable through a keyboard interface alone
Do: Ensure all interactive elements are reachable and activatable via keyboard
Don't: Rely on mouse-only events like onClick on a <div> without keyboard handlers

Description: Custom interactive components must handle appropriate keyboard events
Do: Implement onKeyDown for Enter/Space on custom components with proper roles
Don't: Create clickable divs without keyboard event handling or ARIA roles
Code Example Good: { if (e.key === 'Enter' || e.key === ' ') handleClick(); }} onClick={handleClick}>Action

Description: Users must be able to navigate away from any component using only the keyboard
Do: Ensure Tab and Shift+Tab move focus naturally and modals trap focus correctly within themselves
Don't: Create components where keyboard focus gets stuck with no way to exit
Code Example Good: <dialog open><button>Close</button></dialog> /* focus trapped in dialog, Esc closes */
Code Example Bad: /* no focus management, Tab escapes to background */

Description: If single character key shortcuts exist provide a way to turn off remap or activate only on focus
Do: Allow users to disable or remap single-character shortcuts
Don't: Implement global single-key shortcuts (like 's' for search) that cannot be disabled
Code Example Good: /* Shortcut only active when search input is focused */ input.onKeyDown((e) => { if (e.key === '/') openSearch(); })

Description: Provide a mechanism to skip repeated blocks of content like navigation
Do: Add a visually hidden skip link as the first focusable element that jumps to main content
Don't: Force users to tab through the entire navigation on every page
Code Example Good:
Skip to main content
...
Code Example Bad: /* No skip link, 30 nav items before main content */

Description: Keyboard focus indicator must be clearly visible on all interactive elements
Do: Use :focus-visible with a prominent outline that meets contrast requirements
Don't: Remove all focus styles with outline:none or use focus indicators that are barely visible

Description: If a time limit exists users must be able to turn off adjust or extend it
Do: Warn users before timeout and provide option to extend the session
Don't: Silently expire sessions or auto-submit forms without warning
Code Example Good: /* Show modal 60s before timeout */ if (timeRemaining < 60) showExtendModal();
Code Example Bad: /* Session expired, redirect to login with no warning */ setTimeout(() => redirect('/login'), 300000);

Description: Moving blinking or auto-updating content must have pause stop or hide controls
Do: Provide visible controls to pause any auto-advancing carousel or animation
Don't: Auto-play carousels with no pause button or auto-scrolling content with no stop mechanism

Description: Content must not flash more than three times per second
Do: Avoid flashing content entirely or keep below threshold of three flashes per second
Don't: Use rapid strobing effects blinking text or flashing banner advertisements
Code Example Good: /* Gentle fade transition */ .alert { transition: opacity 0.3s ease; }
Code Example Bad: /* Rapid flash effect */ @keyframes flash { 0%,50% { opacity: 0; } 25%,75% { opacity: 1; } } .alert { animation: flash 0.2s infinite; }

Description: Every page must have a descriptive and unique title that describes its purpose
Do: Set descriptive page titles that include page name and site name
Don't: Use the same generic title on every page or leave the default framework title
Code Example Good: <title>Shopping Cart - My Store</title> /* or Next.js metadata export */

Description: Focus order must be logical and follow the visual reading order of the page
Do: Let natural DOM order determine focus sequence and use tabIndex='0' when needed
Don't: Use positive tabIndex values (tabIndex='5') which create unpredictable focus order

Description: The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or with its context
Do: Use descriptive link text that makes sense out of context
Don't: Use vague link text like 'click here' or 'read more' without additional context

Description: More than one way is available to locate a page within a set of pages
Do: Provide navigation menu plus search and/or sitemap
Don't: Offer only a single navigation method with no search or alternative paths
Code Example Good: /* Site has: main nav + search bar + breadcrumbs + sitemap page */
Code Example Bad: /* Only way to find pages is through a single hamburger menu */

Description: Headings and labels describe the topic or purpose of the content they introduce
Do: Write headings and labels that clearly describe their section or input purpose
Don't: Use vague headings like 'Section 1' or form labels like 'Field' that give no context

Description: Any keyboard operable UI has a visible focus indicator in all states
Do: Ensure focus indicators remain visible even when elements are partially obscured
Don't: Allow sticky headers or overlapping elements to completely hide the focus indicator
Code Example Good: button:focus-visible { outline: 3px solid #2563eb; outline-offset: 2px; position: relative; z-index: 1; }
Code Example Bad: /* Focus outline hidden behind sticky header with no z-index management */

Description: When a UI component receives focus it is not entirely hidden by author-created content
Do: Ensure sticky headers and footers do not completely cover focused elements
Don't: Let fixed-position banners or sticky navs fully obscure the focused element
Code Example Good: /* Scroll focused element into view */ element.scrollIntoView({ block: 'nearest' }); /* Plus scroll-padding-top for sticky header */
Code Example Bad: /* Sticky header covers focused links below it with no scroll compensation */

Description: Functionality using dragging movements can be operated with a single pointer without dragging
Do: Provide click-based alternatives for all drag-and-drop interactions
Don't: Require drag-and-drop as the only way to reorder items or move content
Code Example Good:
{items.map(item => (
{item.name}
))}
Code Example Bad: /* Only drag handles, no button alternatives for reordering */

Description: Interactive targets must be at least 24x24 CSS pixels or have sufficient spacing
Do: Ensure buttons and links have at least 24x24px target area with adequate spacing
Don't: Create tiny icon buttons or tightly packed link lists with targets smaller than 24px
Code Example Good: button { min-width: 44px; min-height: 44px; } /* WCAG AAA is 44px, AA is 24px minimum */

Description: Functionality requiring multipoint or path-based gestures has single-pointer alternative
Do: Provide button alternatives for pinch-zoom swipe and multi-finger gestures
Don't: Require two-finger pinch or complex swipe patterns with no alternative controls
Code Example Good: /* Alternative to pinch zoom */
Code Example Bad: /* Map only supports pinch-to-zoom with no button controls */

Description: Pagination and page break controls must be keyboard accessible and clearly labeled
Do: Use proper nav landmark with aria-label for pagination with clear current page indication
Don't: Use unlabeled div-based pagination that is not keyboard accessible

Description: The default human language of each page can be programmatically determined
Do: Set the lang attribute on the <html> element to the correct language code
Don't: Omit the lang attribute or set it to the wrong language

Description: Parts of content in a different language from the page default are identified
Do: Use the lang attribute on elements containing text in a different language
Don't: Mix languages without marking the language change on inline elements
Code Example Good: The French term mise en place means everything in its place.
Code Example Bad: The French term mise en place means everything in its place.

Description: A mechanism is available for identifying definitions of unusual words or jargon
Do: Provide a glossary tooltip or link to definition for technical terms and abbreviations
Don't: Use unexplained jargon acronyms or domain-specific terms without any definition
Code Example Bad: WCAG /* no expansion or definition provided */

Description: Receiving focus on a component does not trigger an unexpected change of context
Do: Keep focus events for visual changes only like showing a tooltip
Don't: Navigate to a new page or open a popup when an element receives focus

Description: Changing a form input does not automatically cause an unexpected change of context
Do: Warn users before input changes trigger context changes or use a submit button
Don't: Auto-submit forms or navigate away when a dropdown selection changes
Code Example Good: <select onChange={(e) => setFilter(e.target.value)}><option>Filter results</option></select> /* updates in-page only */

Description: Navigation mechanisms repeated across pages occur in the same relative order
Do: Keep nav items in the same order across all pages with consistent placement
Don't: Rearrange navigation links differently on each page or section of the site
Code Example Good: /* Same <Header /> component used across all pages with identical nav order */
Code Example Bad: /* Different nav order on /about vs /pricing vs /docs */

Description: Components with the same functionality are identified consistently across pages
Do: Use the same label icon and behavior for search buttons across the entire site
Don't: Label the search feature 'Search' on one page 'Find' on another and 'Look up' on a third
Code Example Bad: /* Home: 'Search' | About: 'Find' | Docs: 'Look up' â€” same function different labels */

Description: Input errors are automatically detected and described to the user in text
Do: Show specific error messages next to the invalid field with aria-describedby
Don't: Show only a red border with no text explanation of what went wrong
Code Example Good: Please enter a valid email address.

Description: Form inputs have visible labels or instructions that describe expected input
Do: Use visible <label> elements associated with inputs via htmlFor/id
Don't: Rely solely on placeholder text as the only label for form inputs

Description: When an input error is detected and suggestions are known they are provided to the user
Do: Suggest the correct format or valid options when the user makes an input error
Don't: Only say 'Invalid input' without explaining what valid input looks like
Code Example Good: Invalid date. Please use the format MM/DD/YYYY (e.g. 02/20/2026).

Description: For pages with legal or financial commitments allow review confirmation or reversal
Do: Provide a review step before final submission and allow users to undo or cancel
Don't: Submit financial transactions on a single click with no confirmation or review step
Code Example Good:
Review your order

Total: $99

Description: Information previously entered by the user is auto-populated or available for selection
Do: Auto-fill previously entered information or let users select from prior entries
Don't: Force users to re-type their shipping address as billing address on the next step
Code Example Good: <label><input type="checkbox" onChange={copyShipping} /> Billing address same as shipping</label>
Code Example Bad: /* Step 2 requires manually re-entering all address fields from Step 1 */

Description: Authentication does not require cognitive function tests unless an alternative is provided
Do: Support password managers copy/paste and provide alternatives to text-based CAPTCHAs
Don't: Block paste in password fields or require memorized CAPTCHA text with no alternative

Description: All UI components have accessible names and roles that can be programmatically determined
Do: Use native HTML elements or add proper ARIA roles names and states to custom components
Don't: Create custom interactive components without any ARIA attributes or semantic markup

Description: Status messages can be programmatically determined without receiving focus
Do: Use aria-live regions or role='status' to announce dynamic content changes
Don't: Update text on the page silently so screen reader users miss important status changes

Description: ARIA roles states and properties are used correctly following the WAI-ARIA specification
Do: Use ARIA attributes that match the element role and keep states synchronized with UI
Don't: Add random ARIA attributes that contradict the element behavior or native semantics

Description: Live regions are used appropriately to announce dynamic content to screen readers
Do: Use aria-live='polite' for non-urgent updates and 'assertive' only for critical alerts
Don't: Make every dynamic update assertive or use too many simultaneous live regions
Code Example Good:
Item added to cart.
Payment failed. Please try again.
Code Example Bad:
You have 3 items.
Welcome back!
New message!

Description: Interactive elements with no visible text must have accessible names via ARIA
Do: Use aria-label for icon buttons and aria-describedby for supplemental instructions
Don't: Leave icon-only buttons without any accessible name so screen readers say 'button'

Description: Respect user preference for reduced motion by disabling or reducing animations
Do: Wrap all animations in a prefers-reduced-motion media query
Don't: Play complex animations regardless of user motion preference settings
Code Example Bad: /* All users get the same heavy animations regardless of preference */
Testing: toggle reduced motion in OS + visual test

Description: Parallax and scroll-linked effects have accessible alternatives that do not cause discomfort
Do: Disable parallax effects when prefers-reduced-motion is set and keep content readable
Don't: Use aggressive parallax scrolling with no option to disable for vestibular-sensitive users
Code Example Bad: /* Parallax always active, triggers motion sickness for some users */

Description: Auto-playing video must be muted by default with visible pause and volume controls
Do: Autoplay only when muted and always provide visible pause/stop controls
Don't: Autoplay video with sound and no way to pause or mute it
Code Example Good: <video autoPlay muted loop playsInline><source src="hero.mp4" /></video><button onClick={togglePlay}>Pause</button>
Code Example Bad: <video autoPlay loop><source src="hero.mp4" /></video> /* sound + no controls */

Description: Keep decorative animations subtle and short to avoid distraction and vestibular triggers
Do: Limit decorative animations to under 5 seconds and keep movement subtle
Don't: Use continuous looping large-scale decorative animations that distract from content
Code Example Bad: Content

Description: Page transitions and route changes should avoid large-scale motion that triggers vestibular disorders
Do: Use simple fade or opacity transitions for route changes instead of zoom or slide effects
Don't: Use full-page zoom slide or rotate transitions during navigation
Code Example Good: /* Route transition */ .page-enter { opacity: 0; } .page-enter-active { opacity: 1; transition: opacity 200ms ease; }
Code Example Bad: /* Route transition */ .page-enter { transform: scale(0) rotate(180deg); } .page-enter-active { transform: scale(1) rotate(0); transition: all 600ms; }
Testing: toggle reduced motion + manual navigation test

Keywords: scroll animation, intersection observer, reduced motion
Description: Scroll-triggered animations must respect reduced motion and not block content access
Do: Gate scroll animations behind prefers-reduced-motion and ensure content is visible without them
Don't: Hide content until scroll triggers the reveal animation making it inaccessible if animations fail
Code Example Good: const prefersReduced = window.matchMedia('(prefers-reduced-motion: reduce)').matches; if (prefersReduced) { element.style.opacity = '1'; } else { observer.observe(element); }
Code Example Bad: Important content only visible after scroll animation triggers
